metadata.title: Hand Injuries, Mutilating
synonyms: injuries, hand, mutilating, mutilated hand injuries
anatomical location body part affected: Hand and digits; injury can occur to one or more of the following: integumentary system, nerves, muscles, tendons, ligaments, bones, blood vessels, and any of the other structures of the hand/wrist
description: A mutilating hand injury is a severe injury in which multiple systems and structures are involved, including bones, tendons, soft tissues, nerves, blood vessels, and skin

ICD-10 codes.S66.9: injury of unspecified muscle and tendon at wrist and hand level
ICD-10 codes.S67: crushing injury of wrist, hand and finger(s)
ICD-10 codes.S67.9: crushing injury of unspecified parts of wrist and hand and finger(s)
ICD-10 codes.S69: other and unspecified injuries of wrist, hand and finger(s) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation will vary significantly depending on the nature and extent of the injury, the injured structures, the location of the injury, type of intervention, and the stage of healing

Presentation, signs, and symptoms may include (but are not limited to): –amputation of portions of one or more digits (or the hand itself) –loss of significant areas and layers of skin –skin coverage with flaps or grafts –internal or external fixation of fractures –burns –wounds (e.g., open fractures, post-surgical  wounds) –erythema(1,4,21) –edema(1,4,21) –infection(1,4,21) –pain –loss of sensation –hypersensitivity Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: The mechanism of injury may be a crush injury, traction injury, burn, gunshot wound,chemical burn, electrical burn, laceration, high-pressure  injection, or other type oftraumatic injury(1,2,4,20)
pathogenesis: Pathogenesis will vary significantly based on the type of injury, the severity of injury, and other factors
risk factors: The risk of mutilating hand injuries is present in occupations or other activities that involve the use of machinery, tools,chemicals, and/or exposure to weapons, fire, extreme weather, dangerous animals, etc.

In a study designed to assess the magnitude of utilization of emergency services for hand injuries, investigators found thatthe type of hand injuries presenting to the ERhas a cyclical fluctuation during the year. Open wounds are the most commonhand injury and occur most frequently in young adults(13)

Inappropriate safety procedures and lack of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) or other safety measures canincrease the risk of injury. Examples include:–removing safety guards from machinery, such as power saws or woodchippers–using improper technique–using hands to remove clogs from machinery without shutting off the power (e.g., clogged snow-blower  chute)–operating machinery or vehicles while fatigued or under the influence of alcohol or medications that cause impairment
Children who have hand injuries often sustain crush injuries (e.g., from getting hand crushed in a door), which account for80% of hand injuries in children up to age 6(3)

overall contraindications precautions: If on the scene of an accident, wrap amputated tissue or digits in gauze moistened with saline solution, and put the wrapped tissue/digits in a plastic bag. Then put the bag in a separate bag filled with ice. Putting the tissue directly on ice will damage the tissue(22)

Patients with mutilating hand injuries are at high risk for infection in the affected areas. Monitor the wound carefully for signs of infection. If infection is suspected, the patient should be referred back to the physician/hand surgeon immediately for further evaluation and treatment(1,4,21)
Appropriate dressings should be used, with care taken to avoid maceration of the wound when moist/wet dressings are applied
The use of compression wraps, intermittent compression pumps, paraffin, and other therapy interventions often is contraindicated if infection or open wounds are present
Special care should be taken to protect pins or external fixation devices that may protrude from the hand or digits

ROM of joints should be performed only within the limitations set by the surgeon to avoid damage to nerve, tendon, bone, and skin repairs. Obtain orders from the surgeon regarding what ROM is appropriate and what should be avoided
Use caution if sling use has been prescribed. Patient should not rest hand in a dependent position; this position can increase edema
Whirlpool treatments are contraindicated if acute edema is present due to risk of increasing edema with the hand in a dependent position
The patient may have decreased sensation; instruct in protective techniques to prevent thermal and other injuries
Use caution with all thermal modalities, especially in patients with vascular involvement, who may have an impaired ability to dissipate heat effectively

Strengthening exercises should not be initiated until bone and soft tissue structures can tolerate the force of the muscle contraction; time frame will vary depending upon the injuries and type of repair
Fractures should be healed completely before beginning strengthening exercises
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patient may be referred while in an inpatient facility, within a day or so after injury. Patient may also be referred several days or weeks later in an outpatient facility. Identify the mechanism of injury. Determine what surgical procedures have been performed, what structures were affected (vessels, nerves, bone, tendons, skin), what structures were repaired (vs unrepaired), and condition of repairs. Also important to note is type and stability of skeletal fixation used if fracture occurred during injury; are joints free, pinned, or fused? Identify where open wounds and surgically closed wounds exist

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management can include tetanus vaccination, NSAIDs, narcotic pain medications, and antibiotics. Surgical management will vary depending on the type and extent of injury (e.g., tissue debridement and grafting, amputation, fasciotomy, external fixators, transposition, replantation)(1,19,21)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling pain to allow patient to participate in therapy?
diagnostic tests completed: X-ray,  MRI, CT scan, EMG, vascular testing, and other diagnostic testing may be required to determine which structures have been injured, monitor healing, and make sure that repaired structures remain intact(21)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much ). Assess for pain at rest using a V AS. Patients may have significant postoperative pain and may also have significant pain with active and/or passive ROM (PROM)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to injury
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., worsening pain, fever, nightmares, flashbacks). Mutilating hand injuries are frequently associated with the development of mental health problems such as PTSD and depression(15)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any known respiratory compromise? Does the patient smoke (which can delay healing)? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of previous injuries to the hand? Does the patient have any pertinent medical history (e.g., compromised immune system, circulatory disorders, diabetes) that may delay wound healing?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work? What type of work? Was the injury work-related?  In what recreational or leisure activities does the patient participate? What are the patient’s role functions? Can the patient use the involved hand for activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What is the patient’s hand dominance? What is the patient’s prior level of function? Does the patient require adaptive equipment or adapted techniques to perform ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Is the patient a caregiver? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does patient require any devices to complete ADLs secondary to loss of hand/upper extremity function?
relevant tests and measures.circulation: In severe hand traumas, blood vessel damage may have occurred.(21) Take note of increased pallor, blue color of the finger(s), and coolness of the finger(s). Also, assess capillary refill and skin turgor.(21) How are vascular injuries being managed (e.g., medical leeches)?There is often significant edema and inflammation following severe injury to the hand.(21) Edema may be of the affected digits and hand and may also include the forearm, depending on the location and severity of the injury. If possible, volumetric measurements may be taken; however, if open wounds/infection are present, circumferential measurements may be taken to monitor the severity of edema (e.g., fourth digit proximal interphalangeal [PIP] joint circumference, 2nd through 4th metacarpophalangeal [MCP] joint circumference, circumference at wrist crease). Note presence of pitting edemaContracture of the distal interphalangeal (DIP), PIP, MCP, or wrist joints may occur secondary to immobilization of the wrist, hand, and digits following mutilating hand injuries. In some cases, the digits may be lost to amputation (traumatic or surgical). The scapholunate ligament is the most commonly injured intrinsic ligament(23)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle testing usually is inappropriate in the early stages following mutilating hand injuries and subsequent surgical interventions. When appropriate (permitted through physician order), muscle grip and pinch strength testing (i.e., tip pinch, lateral pinch, and gross grasp) may be conducted using a Jamar dynamometer and pinch gauge testing, as well as manual muscle testing of the wrist and forearm
observation inspection palpation includi: In mutilating hand injuries, significant injuries to the skin may exist. If possible, the involved layers of the skin are sutured. However, in some cases open wounds may be left to heal without surgical intervention. In cases of severe injury, skin flaps or grafts may be used to cover large open areas. Surgical incisions should be assessed for intact sutures, and all wounds should be assessed for signs of infection (erythema, warmth, inappropriate drainage, odor), appropriate healing, etc. •Positioning: Check that wrist, MCP joints, PIP joints, and DIP joints are positioned correctly in any postoperative orthoses. Position will vary depending upon involved structures (e.g., PIP flexion with PIP dislocation; PIP extension with MCP fracture) and physician preference. Monitor for changes in postoperative dressing bulk, causing need to adjust position in orthosis
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Determine range of motion (AROM or PROM as appropriate) within the parameters established by the physician/hand surgeon (which joints may be mobilized, specific ROM restrictions) Self-care/ADLs –Assess ability to complete ADLs –If there has been amputation of the thumb or a significant portion of the hand or digits, a prosthesis may be required to provide functional opposition and use of the hand for daily activities
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –If nerve damage/traction/repair has occurred, significant sensory impairment may be present(5) –Sensory changes should be documented.(21) Semmes-Weinstein  monofilament testing, two-point discrimination testing, and other sensation testing should be performed in the median, ulnar, or dorsal radial sensory nerve distributions as appropriate based on the location of the injury –Identify areas that may be hypersensitive to stimulation –The Tinel sign and sensory testing should be used frequently to monitor the status of nerve regeneration
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure  -For additional information on the DASH, see  Clinical Review….Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number T903177 –Manual Ability Measure-36  (MAM-36)(18) –International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (ICF) Core Sets for Hand Conditions(6,7)(8) -Ability to pick up small objects -Ability to obtain objects from a pocket -Ability to open a zipper -Ability to unlock a door -Standardized hand function tests include -Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test -9-hole  peg test -Boxes and blocks test

contraindications precautions: Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema
More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy

Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis

Neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) is contraindicated wherever active muscle contraction is contraindicated (e.g., newly sutured tendons) -Do not place electrodes nearcarotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen
In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck
History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
In the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocol
Obtain physician orders and parameters prior to initiating any new interventions
Shoulder protection: Modify or discontinue activities that provoke pain
Whirlpool  precautions (*some are relevant only if entire body is immersed)(9)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Mutilating hand injury resulting in bone, skin, nerve, vascular, ligament, tendon, and other soft tissue damage or loss. The patient will require physical and/or occupational therapy to address wound care, edema, orthosis fabrication, ROM/strength/functional losses, and other deficits
prognosis: The prognosis for patients with mutilating hand injuries varies depending on the extent of the injury. Time off work varies based on diagnosis and job demands. Patients with amputations, scaphoid fractures, and proximal phalanx fractures had the longest duration of complaints in prospective study conducted in the Netherlands(24)

Results of a systematic review that included 8 studies showed that return to work occurred by 6 months in over 60% of individuals with work-related  traumatic hand injuries(17) –Persons with more severe impairments and lower preinjury income were less likely to return to work –Age, sex, and level of education had no impact on return to work

Early and appropriate treatment can result in fewer complications and better outcomes in pediatric patients with hand injuries(19) –Treatment that was delayed (greater than 48 hours post injury) or that did not include debridement, open reduction, nail bed repair, and antibiotic therapy resulted in a greater rate of complications, including osteomyelitis
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapist for ADLs training, orthosis fabrication Prosthetist for prosthetic digits, gloves, hands, and other equipment Physician if infection, wound dehiscence, or other abnormality is suspected or identified Psychologist if there are adjustment issues post trauma/surgery V ocational counselor Certified hand therapist as indicated and/or available
other considerations: Tenolysis (surgical release of adhesions) may be necessary 6–12  months post initial surgery if tendon gliding is insufficient
Rehabilitation in a group setting may facilitate psychological and physical recovery from mutilating hand injuries(10)
treatment summary: In the early stages of recovery, the primary goals of therapy are to facilitate wound healing and prevent infection. Other goals of therapy are to control edema, improve PROM, and prevent contracture
In the later phases of rehabilitation, scar management, increasing passive and active ROM and strength, and improving hand function are the primary goals

Significant evidence-based  research is lacking in the rehabilitation of mutilating hand injuries, but clinical experience and expertise help to form a comprehensive and effective rehabilitation program . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain Decrease pain Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Various modalities and physical agents can be effective in pain relief, but the choice of which modality/agent to apply depends on the specific nature of the mutilating injury(8)Modalities or physical agents may be effective in relieving pain and tendernessProvide recommendations for home regarding pain relief  Edema Reduce edema Manual therapy _ Retrograde massage may control edema of the wrist, hand, and fingers. AROM exercises also help to produce a natural muscle pumping action to assist with lymphatic drainage and the reduction of edema and can be incorporated into the treatment program if not contraindicated _ _ Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ The use of intermittent compression pumps, compression gloves, self-adherent wrap, and other anti-edema equipment can help to reduce edema. Patient education to maintain elevation is essentialEdema should be effectively reduced with continued therapyPatient may be provided with methods of safely reducing edema at home (e.g., positioning, retrograde massage)  Healing open wounds/ surgical woundsFacilitate healing as able; prevent scar adhesionsOrthosis fabrication _ The specific type of orthosis required depends on the type and location of injury, as well as if an amputation has resulted in the loss of digits or part of the hand _ _ In general, a resting orthosis may be used, with the joints positioned as follows: slight wrist extension (15–20°), MCP joints in 70–80°flexion, the IP joints near full extension, and the thumb extended and abducted(11) _ _ Protective orthoses will need to be remolded as edema decreases and the amount of wound dressing is reduced _ _ Patients with nerve, tendon, or vascular repairs may require different positioning to protect the repairs and reduce tension on the structures involved _ _ _ Dynamic orthoses may allow for early mobilization (e.g., dynamic traction for flexor tendon rehabilitation) while providing protection for involved joints and soft tissue structures _ _ Orthosis fabrication decisions should be made in consultation with the surgeon so that all members of the rehabilitation team are aware of the restrictions warranted by certain injuries and surgical interventions _ _ Wound care _ Close communication with the surgeon is required for the appropriate choice of dressings and ointments _ _ Whirlpool may be used to facilitate debridement of open wounds but should be used cautiously because of the dependent position required, which increases edema _ _ If permitted by the surgeon, the therapist may be involved in debridement of eschar and other wound careCaring for the wound may help reduce infection and improve healing time _ _ Scar management _ Scar massage should be performed once adequate wound healing is achieved. Increased scar thickness and adherence can reduce skin mobility and the amount of tendon excursion, limiting ROM, strength, and functionProvide oral and written instruction on protection of injury and methods of facilitating healing  Reduced digital/wrist ROMIncrease digital/wrist ROMManual therapy _ PROM should be applied as appropriate, depending on the specific injuries and surgeon restrictions _ _ Early application of stress to repaired soft tissue structures has been shown to affect scar remodeling; studies have demonstrated a faster recovery of tensile strength, decreased adhesion formation, better tendon excursion, and less deformation at the tendon site(12) _ _ Therapeutic exercise _ AROM of the wrist and digits should be initiated as soon as it is safe. At this time, blocking exercises of the PIP and DIP joints may be used to help isolate each joint _ _ Adequate support to the proximal joint is necessary to allow for isolated flexion and extension of the joint. AROM of the MCP joints, AROM wrist extension/flexion, and forearm pronation/ supination should be performed as appropriate _ _ Nerve and tendon gliding (hook fist, full fist, straight fist, tabletop) and intrinsic plus minus positioning may also be incorporated using 3 sets of 15 repetitions _ _ Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Moist heat packs, ultrasound, and paraffin may be used, as allowed by physician, to increase tissue elasticity prior to manual therapy and stretching exercisesProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home program that incorporates ROM as indicated  Reduced grip/muscle strength _ _ Impaired functionIncrease grip/muscle strength _ _ Improve hand functionTherapeutic exercise _ Once the patient begins to achieve increased AROM, initiate gentle and progressive strengthening when safe to begin _ _ The use of therapy putty, hand grippers, light hand weights/ sticks, rubber bands, resisted clothespins, and other hand therapy equipment may be incorporated to increase grip strength, pinch strength, wrist flexion and extension strength, and pronation/ supination strength _ _ These exercises should be introduced only when deemed appropriate by the surgeon and the therapist, and will vary based on the injury and the surgical interventions performed _ _ These exercises should be performed in a pain-free range and progressed slowly to the patient’s tolerance. Each exercise may be performed in 3 sets of 15 repetitions _ Electrotherapeutic modalities _ NMES may be used in appropriate cases to facilitate the return of muscular contraction and function and prevent atrophy while nerve regeneration occursFunctional training _ Introduce functional strengthening and gradual implementation of typical daily activities as symptoms improve (after pain, edema, ROM, and strength issues have been addressed) _ _ This may include dexterity activities, such as handling and counting change, locking and unlocking doors/padlocks, and removing small objects from therapy putty _ _ Work-simulation activities may also be appropriate in later stages _ _ Gravity-dependent position tolerance training can begin once the wound is healed and edema and vascularization are stable. Patients may begin to do this on their own as they start to use the hand for functional activities _ _If appropriate, a home program can be given to improve results  If appropriate, a home program can be given to improve resultsReduce hypersensitivities as able _ _ Increase patient knowledge on risk of injury/prevention of injury following sensory impairmentSensory reeducation _ May use different textures, such as cotton, silk, or rice, to decrease hypersensitivity _ _ Use of “scrubbing” technique across the affected area to stimulate hypersensitive areas _ _ “Particle baths,” using tubs of progressively challenging textures (rice, Styrofoam pieces, sand), are also helpful _ _ Weight-bearing activities should also be incorporated: cleaning table with rag while putting weight through palm of hand, leaning through hands to make small circles with physioball, carrying weighted objects in affected extremity, and other activities to address the possibility of reflex sympathetic dystrophy _ _ Use of these techniques may be contraindicated with open wounds or in the presence of infectionProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedRecommend strategies for home as indicated .

reduced edema: Circumferential or volumetric measures as appropriate
improved function: International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (ICF) Core Sets for Hand Conditions(6,7)

maintenance or prevention: Home exercise program to maintain ROM/strength/function of the affected hand. Proper safety procedures and equipment in situations that increase risk of injury to the hand (machine/tool/chemical use) can help to decrease the incidence and severity of injury
Elbow and shoulder exercises should also be incorporated into a regular routine
patient education: See “Fingertip Injuries and Amputations” from the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons at https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/en/diseases--conditions/fingertip-injuries-and-amputations
